summary.p: Sol meldunensis was a gift to the sun and moon of MalmesburyMalmesbury, Benedictine abbey of St Peter and St Paul, Geoffrey, abbot from 1246 to 1260Geoffrey, of Malmesbury, –1260. It is a miscellany of the works of Alexander Neckam (1157–1217)Neckam, Alexander, 1157–1217 alongside Geoffrey of Monmouth (died 1154/5)Geoffrey, of Monmouth, –1154/5, Peter of Blois (died 1212)Peter, of Blois, –1212, and Robert de Beaufeu (died in or before 1219)Robert, de Beaufeu, –1219??, with shorter passages from Reginald of Canterbury (fl. 1100s)Reginald, of Canterbury, fl. 1100s, Hildebert of Lavardin (died 1133)Hildebert, of Lavardin, –1133, and Serlo of Wilton (died 1181)Serlo, of Wilton, –1181.

The main part of the volume (ff. 3–212) is a florilegium by Geoffrey Brito (fl. 1210s–1240s)Brito, Geoffrey, fl. 1210s–1240s, a canon at Cirencester AbbeyCirencester, Augustinian abbey of St Mary the Virgin and the nephew of Alexander NeckamNeckam, Alexander, 1157–1217. He combines and adapts extracts from Alexander’s works into a continuous theological treatise in two books. The work closes with an aspiration for the two Geoffreys to maintain a correspondence (f. 212v).

The volume includes several structurally separate but contemporary additions. An inserted leaf of tinted drawings of St FrancisFrancis, of Assisi, Saint, 1182–1226 (f. 5r) and St DominicDominic, Saint, 1170–1221 (f. 5v) alongside companion friars is stylistically contemporaneous with the manuscript, placing it among the first examples of these figures in English art. An inserted quire of Geoffrey of MonmouthGeoffrey, of Monmouth, –1154/5, Prophetia Merlini (ff. 213–222), is only connected to the preceding text through the prominence of the names Geoffrey and Alexander, but it includes added decoration (f. 214r) by the volume’s original creators. The final part is a anthology including poetry debating the merits of wine and beer, versifications of the fables of AvianusAvianus, Flavius, 4th–5th centuries, and other satirical and didactic poems in Latin and Anglo-Norman (ff. 223–237). These additions could be interpreted as an enactment of Geoffrey’s desire to foster a collaboration between CirencesterCirencester, Augustinian abbey of St Mary the Virgin and MalmesburyMalmesbury, Benedictine abbey of St Peter and St Paul.

Dr Andrew Dunning
R.W. Hunt Curator of Medieval Manuscripts
Bodleian Library, University of Oxford

supportDesc.foliation: 19th-century foliation, 1–70 + 70bis + 71–237. Written in pencil in the lower right-hand corner of the recto of the first leaf of each quire, by Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831–1886, University Librarian 1867–1886. He also provides a collation formula: 2 flyleaves. 112 (10 cancelled) 2–610 710 (2 cancelled) 8–910 1012 (11 cancelled) 11–2110 | 2210 | 2310 2410 (wants 5–10): 237 ff (out of 242; 238–42 lost; 70bis an inserted slip; 92 misbound after 93) (f. [ii] recto). Bradshaw appears to have taken one of the parchment stations in the binding for a cancelled leaf: f. 92 is part of quire 9 rather than 10, and though its text seems intended to be read after f. 93v (which his foliation labels 92) there is no evidence that the leaf itself was ever placed there. He also adds signature numbers throughout, with the first folio of each quire numbered in the right-hand foot and an x marked in the same place on the recto immediately following the centre of the quire. H.L. PinkPink, H. L., c. 1958 completed Bradshaw’s foliation in the upper right-hand corner of the recto of each leaf.

additions.p: Annotated by one or two Gothic textura hands, 13th century: ff. 9r, 28r, 13v–14r, 34v, 166r, 214v, 224r, 225r, 235r, 237v. The addition on f. 166r is later framed by the original decorator (cf. the integrated additions on ff. 172r and 183r). The annotation on f. 235r is corrected by the plummet annotator, implying that this is either a canon of CirencesterCirencester, Augustinian abbey of St Mary the Virgin or a monk of MalmesburyMalmesbury, Benedictine abbey of St Peter and St Paul.

Annotated in plummet with many added nota marks and corrections, some of which are later executed by the original scribes. Some of the corrections are presumably by Geoffrey BritoBrito, Geoffrey, fl. 1210s–1240s, and some of the contemporary annotations may also be from Geoffrey of MalmesburyGeoffrey, of Malmesbury, –1260. There are at least two hands adding similar nota marks: ff. 4r, 4v, 11r, 11v, 13r, 13v, 14r, 16v, 17r, 20r, 20v, 21r, 21v, 28r, 29v, 30r, 31r, 35r, 37v, 41v, 43r, 50r, 51r, 61v, 62v, 63r, 64r, 64v, 65r, 67v, 69r, 72v, 73r, 73v, 76v, 77r, 77v, 78r, 79r, 85r, 85v, 86r, 87v, 88r, 89r, 90r, 92r, 93r, 93v, 95r, 96r, 96v, 97v, 99v, 101v, 102v, 103v, 104r, 105v, 107r, 112r, 112v, 114v, 116v, 117v, 123v, 126r, 128r, 128v, 129r, 130v, 131v, 134r, 136r, 140v, 141r, 142r, 143r, 143v, 144r, 145v, 146v, 148r, 148v, 149r, 150v, 151r, 154r, 157r, 157v, 158r, 159r, 162r, 163v, 165v, 169r, 169v, 170r, 171v, 172r, 174r, 175r, 175v, 176v, 178r, 178v, 180r, 197v, 183r, 183v, 184r, 184v, 185r, 185v, 187r, 189r, 198v, 190r, 190v, 191r, 192r, 192v, 193r, 193v, 194r, 195r, 195v, 197v, 198r, 199v, 200r, 201r, 201v, 202r, 202v, 203r, 206v, 207v, 208v, 208v, 209r, 209v, 210v, 211r, 215r, 217v, 218r, 218v, 219r, 219v, 220v, 221r, 229v, 233r, 234r, 235r, 236r.
Gothic semihybrida marginalia, often beginning with a paraph mark: ff. 9r, 83r, 84r, 86v, 87r (corrections as well as annotations), 87v, 106v, 117v, 123r, 124r.
Added headings by a humanist hand, 16th or 17th century (ff. 3r, 215r).

Thomas Tanner (1674–1735)Tanner, Thomas, 1674–1735 inscribed the opening flyleaf, Galf. de Meldy (f. 1r); his entry on the manuscript in CUL MS Oo.7.50.2 indicates that the text was written per quendam Galfridum monachum. He also added marginalia and running headings, mostly analysing the structure of Sol meldunensis book 2, with occasional annotations to other sections (ff. 74v, 75r, 75v, 86v, 87v, 88r, 89v, 91v, 92r, 93r, 93v, 94r, 94v, 95r, 95v, 96r, 114r, 115r, 116r, 117r, 119r, 121r, 121v, 122r, 122v, 123r, 123v, 125r, 125v, 126r, 127v, 129r, 130r, 131v, 132r, 132v, 133r, 134r, 135r, 136r, 137r, 138r, 139r, 140r, 141r, 166r, 167v, 168r, 170r, 171r, 173v, 174v, 175r, 179r, 180r, 181r, 182r, 183r, 184r, 185r, 186r, 187r, 189r, 190r, 198r, 198v, 201r, 205r, 223v, 224r).
Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831–1886 added quire signatures and a collation formula (ff. 237v–[ii] recto).

binding.p: Full leather with two blind-tooled rectangular frames, 17th century (left cover, outer; right cover, outer). Each quire is sewn onto a parchment station.
Rebacked (spine) by GrayJohn P. Gray & Son Ltd., Cambridge, 1956 (annotation, left cover, inner).

origin.p: The core of the volume, ff. 3–212, was finished at Cirencester Abbey, 1246 × 1260. Oxford, Jesus College, MS. 94, from the abbey, has annotations corresponding to extracts used in Sol meldunensis. The writer names himself Galfridus, who is presumably the nephew of Alexander Neckam (1157–1217)Neckam, Alexander, 1157–1217, Geoffrey BritoBrito, Geoffrey, fl. 1210s–1240s. Geoffrey developed Sol meldunensis as it was being copied, with several layers visible. He repeatedly invites the work’s recipient, Geoffrey, abbot of Malmesbury from 1246 until 1260Geoffrey, of Malmesbury, –1260, to correct his text and collaborate. This is a standard trope of literary patronage and friendship, but the various layers of addition within the volume may reflect this desired exchange between Cirencester and Malmesbury.

provenance.p: Malmesbury AbbeyMalmesbury, Benedictine abbey of St Peter and St Paul: Sol meldunensis is dedicated to Geoffrey of MalmesburyGeoffrey, of Malmesbury, –1260 (ff. 3r, 71v).

? Cirencester AbbeyCirencester, Augustinian abbey of St Mary the Virgin: the inserted miniature of friars (f. 5) and the Geoffrey of Monmouth quire (ff. 213–222) are of an undetermined English origin. Both these and the verse anthology (ff. 223–237) appear to be additions, since Sol meldunensis has a planned conclusion at f. 212v, though not copied with the earlier part of the page; and the additions have a reduced level of annotation in comparison to ff. 3–212. A consistent decoration scheme found across the manuscript (added to Geoffrey of Monmouth at f. 214r) show that all parts of the volume were at one point at Cirencester. A possible interpretation of this evidence is that on receipt of the manuscript, the monks of Malmesbury added marginal additions, the friars miniature, and Geoffrey of Monmouth before returning the manuscript to the canons of Cirencester, who integrated the additions through decoration and appended the verse anthology before sending the book back to Malmesbury.

? Malmesbury AbbeyMalmesbury, Benedictine abbey of St Peter and St Paul: a fifteenth-century inscription may be from the abbey, suggesting that the volume was returned to Cirencester at this time, To Cirencester & bid them pray for me. | He that prayethe for me Jesu have merci on hym. (f. 2v).

Cirencester AbbeyCirencester, Augustinian abbey of St Mary the Virgin: an effaced inscription at the head of f. 3r appears under ultraviolet light to read Cyrencestrie, in a fifteenth- or sixteenth-century hand, similar to inscriptions in other Cirencester manuscripts by John LelandLeland, John, 1506?–1552.

Maurice Gyffard, 16th centuryGyffard, Maurice, 16th century: inscribed, Iste liber constat moritio | Gyffardi Testante Ihesu (f. 2v). The Gyffard or Giffard family was prominent in Cirencester and the name occurs frequently in the abbey’s cartularies.

John Moore (1646–1714), bishop of ElyMoore, John, 1646–1714: no. 131 (f. 1r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (1697); no. 958 (f. 1r) in the handwritten supplementary list of Moore’s manuscripts, now CUL MS Oo.7.50.2, compiled by Thomas Tanner (1674–1735)Tanner, Thomas, 1674–1735, who also annotated the volume extensively.

acquisition.p: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George IGeorge I, King of Great Britain, 1660–1727: donation bookplate engraved by John PinePine, John, 1690–1756 in 1736 on the inside of the left board.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1948 and 1970 by H.L. PinkPink, H. L., now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/75); and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. JamesJames, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862–1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader’s card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

lg.l: Pagina dulce putat cum te mea sponte salutat⹎
O Gaufride pie pater. omnis papa sophie.
Sit precor eius aue tibi gratum dulce suaue.
Esse quidem gratum tibi wlt o uir probitatum⹎
Quod te magnificat de te bona singula dicat.
Grates esse. putes tibi nostras ergo salutes.
Nunc bone Gaufride laus cuius ubique sonatur.
Tucior ut per te sit littera nostra precatur.
Hic si forte tibi liber inconcinna loquatur⹎
Iudex parce sibi ne statim proiciatur.
Sepe relegisse cartam iuuat et meminisse.
Sepius adde manum. quod habebis erit puto planum.

msItem.explicit: 132v Relinquatur hoc uicium iis⹎ qui spectaculis theatralibus obnoxii sunt.

msItem.title: On flatterers and back-biters
msItem.incipit: 132v Adulator⸝ gladio mellelito transfigit cor illius⹎ cui adulatur. Detractor⸝ absentem⹎ impetit sagitta toxicata. Set dum sagittare gloriatur in obscuro rectos corde⹎ in ipsum sagitta missa reuertitur.
msItem.explicit: 133r Partcius tamen uolens quis detractorem adulantem motare⹎ ipsum cani conferet latranti et cauda blandienti.

msItem.title: That a wise man should not incidentally seek revenge for an injury inflicted upon him through disparagement
msItem.rubric: 133r Quod uir sapiens ulcisci non debeat iniuriam sibi in detractionibus illatam incidenter.
msItem.incipit: 133r Quod autem uir maturi pectoris contempnere propriam debeat iniuriam indetractionibus⹎ docetur in codice iustiniani libro nouo⸝ titulo⹎ siquis maledixerit imperatori.
msItem.explicit: 134v Vt autem philistei caput abscidatur gladio proprio⹎ efficaci ratione dissuasiones inuidie refellamus.

msItem.title: Again on flatterers
msItem.incipit: 134v Adulator⹎ est quartus mortuus ad quem dominus inuitatus⹎ noluit accedere dicens. Dimitte mortuos sepelire mortuos suos. Tu me sequere. Quid est tu me sequere. nisi ueritatem sequere?
msItem.explicit:
135v Et tamen illi⹎
surgebant criste. nichil est quod credere de se
non possit⹎ cum laudatur diis equa potestas.

msItem.title: How the fox deceived the crow with its flattery
msItem.rubric: 135v Qualiter uulpis circumuenit coruum adulatione sua.
msItem.incipit: 135v Refert in apollogo quodam apulleius quod coruus et uulpecula ad quandam carrunculam tendebant pari uoto⹎ set dispari celeritate.
msItem.explicit: 136r Excecat enim mentem adulatio et dum animum inpudenter extollit⹎ in proprie infirmitatis obliuionem˷ hominem adducit.

msItem.title: On flattery
msItem.incipit: 136r Adulatio⹎ uenenum est melle litum˷ aut mel uenenatum. Huiusmodi mel prohibetur in lege offerri super altare. eo quod precipue ab iis rebus que ad cultum sancte religionis pertinent⹎ procul relegari debet uicium⸝ adulationis.
msItem.explicit: 137v Adulatio nempe⹎ osculum est iude proditoris. Set quid? Meliora sunt uulnera amici⹎ quam oscula inimici.

msItem.title: On self-aggrandizement
msItem.incipit: 137v Ambitio ceca nichil relinquit absconditum⹎ circa terrena semper occupata. Hec est que cogit homines discrimina subire dum inpenetrale telluris. beneficio artis intratur⹎ et uelut in thesauris suis natura locuples inquiritur.
msItem.explicit: 138r Set cum auro tribuat splendidum ruborem⹎ argento confert albissimam lucem. ut mirum sit unam substanciam tradere⹎ quod rebus dissimilibus possit aptari.

msItem.title: On people who seek advancement
msItem.incipit: 138r Quam fuerit letalis et ambitus urbi romane⹎ in gentes docent ruine.
msItem.explicit: 138v Omnes itaque ambitiosi⹎ adulatores sunt˷ simulatores sunt. cupidi sunt.

msItem.title: On hypocrites
msItem.incipit: 138v Ypocrita omnis adulator est. Duplex est. cupidus est⹎ proditor est. supersticiosus est. non est ambidexter cum ayoth⹎ set ambisinister est eius dextera repleri desiderat muneribus. set eius dextera⹎ sinistra est.
msItem.explicit: 140r Nouos ritus immo superstitiones et excogitant⹎ ut religionis gloriam assecuti uideantur.

msItem.title: On hypocrites
msItem.incipit: 140r Abitiosa res est ypocrisis. et preesse cupit⹎ non prodesse. Non cessat ypocrita laborare. set laudem humanam⹎ fructum laboris sui reputat.
msItem.explicit: 140r Set non saciantur oculi eius interiores diuiciis adspirat enim ad dignitates et suspirat.

msItem.title: On those who covet rewards
msItem.incipit: 140r Suspecta erunt munera uiro prudenter consideranti. qui legantur fuisse munerum acceptores in sacra scriptura.
msItem.explicit: 140v Est enim munus a lingua. ab obsequio⹎ a manu.

msItem.title: Against those who covet rewards
msItem.incipit: 140v Quam detestabile autem sit uicium istud⹎ docent antiqui patres qui munera nec respicere uolebant.
msItem.explicit: 159v Res attendamus⹎ non est fuga si fugiamus. fuga enim discretionis precipitur. fuga timoris⹎ permittitur.

msItem.title: On the duty of prelates
msItem.incipit: 159v Tria item sunt officia⹎ dignitati prelati annexa. Vnum est⹎ ut indulgeat causarum cognitioni. secundum⹎ uerbum doctrine gregem sibi commissum fideliter instruat. tercium⹎ ut cum samaritano uulneribus sauciati infundat vinum austere correptionis⹎ et oleum lenissime consolationis.
msItem.explicit: 166r Eritis sicut dii. scientes bonum et malum⹎ stultissimus autem est qui scientiam aliis inuidus impartiri˷ cum distributa felix suscipiat incrementum.

msItem.title: On the envy of Aristotle
msItem.incipit: 166r Inuitus autem scripto commendarem quod aristotiles peste tam letali inuidia scilicet laborauerit⹎ nisi proposuissem monstrum tam perniciosum cum ceteris uiciis sugillare.
msItem.explicit: 167r Cum autem in omni doctrina philosophica primatum teneret⹎ solam tamen medicinam professus est.

msItem.title: Verses on how Aristotle prevented a war that Alexander declared in Athens
msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.incipit: 167r Magnus alexander. bellum mandarat athenis.
msItem.explicit: 167r Dat pacem lusus calliditate uiri.

msItem.title: On the envy of Macedo
msItem.incipit: 167v Macedo discipulus aristotilis nimis expresse preceptorem suum uolens imitari⸝ cum orbem sibi subhastaret⹎ uicio iam sepedicto colla submisit. Prodolor. orbis triumphator⹎ a uicio tam turpi triumphari sustinuit.
msItem.explicit: 167v Maluit plures relinquere successores. quam parem sibi substituere aliquem.

msItem.title: On the envy and pride of Lucifer
msItem.incipit: 167v Lucifer genus cuius omnis lapis preciosus operimentum erat˷ minus limpide uidit⹎ dum creatori suo inuidit. O quanta sapientia. quam acuto intellectu⹎ preditus erat.
msItem.explicit: 168r Non enim dignus est uenia⹎ qui ex propria malicia tantum in se mittens manus⹎ se ipsum perimit.

msItem.title: The ancient adversaries of pride, envy, and vainglory
msItem.incipit: 168r Associentur igitur superbia et inuidia˷ et inanis gloria. que hostem antiquuum sollicitauit et uicium ingratitudinis. et ambitio presumptuosa. et presumptio ambitiosa. cum tanto creatoris contemptu⹎ et aduertes monstrum istud nulla uirtute redimendum.
msItem.explicit: 170r Ecce columba mea in foraminibus petre et in cauerna macerie.

msItem.title: On the inconstancy of cloistered people
msItem.incipit: 170r Claustrales non nulli⹎ cenobia mutant adeo ut quidam a cellis ad monasteria⹎ alii a monasteriis ad cellas transeant. set in uocatione qua quia uocatus est⹎ maneat.
msItem.explicit: 170v Audi. calidius est narsturtium aquaticum quod in aquis crescit quam ortalanum locus tibi pacem non dabit⹎ nisi tu tecum fedus ineas.

msItem.title: On the wandering movements of cloistered people
msItem.incipit: 170v Vir claustralis intra septa murorum tutus erit qui multas reperit insidias. dum paradysi sui claustrum loquor⹎ tranquillitatem paruipendit. Antiquus enim hostis uiro insidiatur intra septa constantie et stabilis propositi latitanti⹎ usque dum lapidem obstinationis⹎ iniciat intra claustra rationis.
msItem.explicit: 171r A demonibus ut fertur eripiuntur a quibus tuti sunt quamdiu intra certum ferentiam circuli includuntur.

msItem.title: That the lot of cloistered people is happy
msItem.incipit: 171r Condicionum uarietates quibus status hominum sunt obnoxii⹎ considera diligentius. et cernes uitam claustralium. tam tranquillitatis quam securitatis quam honestatis ratione ceteris esse preferendam.
msItem.explicit: 173v Vilis⹎ ut paruus sit in oculis suis. carus⹎ adeo ut uiciis subiacere dedignetur.

msItem.title: On the disturbers of brotherly peace
msItem.rubric: 173v Ex capitulo tercio libri primi de naturis rerum.
msItem.incipit: 173v Ad premissa igitur reuertamur in quibus docemur quia perturbatores pacis et tranquillitatis fratrum⹎ a consortio ipsorum digni sunt eici. ne quorundam pestifera contagione˷ totus grex corrumpatur.
msItem.explicit: 174v Terra nostra⹎ in celum subleuabitur. si tamen in terra⹎ celestis conuersationis efficiamur.

msItem.title: Again on pride and envy
msItem.incipit: 174v Eiecta est superbia de terra uiuentium⹎ quia locus excelsus˷ humilitati se debet. sicut infimus locus⹎ superbie competit.
msItem.explicit: 175r Funes ceciderunt michi in preclaris˷ etenim hereditas mea⹎ preclara est michi.

msItem.title: On envy
msItem.incipit: 175r Quam detestabilis pestis sit inuidia⹎ uix manu notarii aut stili officio potest excipi.
msItem.explicit: 178r Sic quidem te fili mali conueniunt ut te et alios circumueniant. set non semper feriet quodcumque minabitur arcus⹎ Vt in relatione subitienda continebitur.

msItem.title: On the hawk and the weasel
msItem.incipit: 178r Nisum quemdam humi residentem˷ mustela clandestinis insidiis arripuit. que dum excitio capitis illius immineret. ille uno pede non segniter apprehendens eam⹎ arctissime eam constrinxit.
msItem.explicit: 179r Qui igitur alii nocere contendit similis est qui gladio se transuerberat⹎ ut alium interficiat.

msItem.title: Again on envy
msItem.incipit: 179r De peste predicta loqui non inutile erit. Regnat enim hec pestis in palaciis principum. set et tuguria pauperum iam iam nimis sibi familiaria et nota ingreditur.
msItem.explicit: 180v Paris quidem hominis illecebris uite remissioris dediti⹎ tipum gerit. qui sapientiam et dignitatem abiiciens˷ figuratas per pallada et iunonem⹎ uoluptati colla submisit.

msItem.title: On envy and vainglory
msItem.rubric: 180v Ex sermone qui sic incipit. Ponite corda uestra.
msItem.incipit: 180v Cadmus dentes serpentis⹎ legitur seminasse. et prosilierunt de terra⹎ milites armati mutuis sese perimentes uulneribus.
msItem.explicit: 181v Multi reputant se amphoras esse blandiente fortuna. cuius dum rota uoluitur⹎ in urceum mutantur.

msItem.title: On envy that arises from vainglory
msItem.rubric: 181v De Invidia que preuenit ex inani gloria.
msItem.incipit: 181v Set que maior inuidia illa˷ quam inanis gloria in cordibus potentum generat. dum etiam incinerati. aliis sepultura egentibus⸝ locum inuident ocupatum? Que maior uanitas?
msItem.explicit: 182r Immo etiam minus eget sepulchro puluis⹎ quam corpus examime.

msItem.title: On arrogance
msItem.incipit: 182r Arrogantia superbie species est. Est autem arrogans⹎ qui neminem pre se hominem ducit. Et ut docet aristotiles⸝ omnis arrogans⹎ odiosus est.
msItem.explicit: 183r Caluicium⹎ capitis deturpatio. fascia⹎ zona que pectora mulierum cingat.

msItem.title: Again on arrogance
msItem.incipit: 183r Cum loquitur arrogans⹎ nunc taydem imitari quadam mollicie fracte uocis et ficte pronuntiationis. et compositis blesi sermonis lenociniis utendo. nunc capaneum ore intonantem˷ et capulo manum admouentem. representare uidetur.
msItem.explicit: 184r Fenum quasi bos comedit⹎ qui regalium lauticia cibariorum splendidissime usus fuerat.

msItem.title: On the stiff neck of Ishmael
msItem.incipit: 184r Eiectus est ismael et exclusus a paterna hereditate. Nunquid quia filius erat ancille? Quid? Nonne omnes filii iacob pro parte uirili iure hereditario patri successerunt?
msItem.explicit: 184v Quantum igitur sit uitium superbie aduertatis˷ cum ysmaelem a paterna hereditate ceruix erecta eiecerit. cum tamen ruben qui cubile patris sui ascendit⹎ ab hereditate paterna non sit exclusus.

msItem.title: Ecclesiasticus on pride
msItem.incipit: 184v In ecclesiastico autem reperies capitulum de superbia⹎ in quo⸝ sic legitur.
msItem.explicit: 184v Monstrum igitur superbie˷ precipue suggilat assidua mortis meditatio⹎ uel saltem frequens.

msItem.title: Against envy
msItem.rubric: 184v Ex sermone qui sic incipit. Ductus est iesus.
msItem.incipit: 184v Quotiens igitur. aut inuidie stimulis agitamur aut odii igne inflammamur. constituamus pre oculis cordis infelicem infelicis exitum caim.
msItem.explicit: 185r Desperans enim prodolor de misericordia diuina tanquam ignorans que et quante sint diuitie munificentie celestis⹎ ait. Maior est iniquitas mea. quam ut ueniam merear.

msItem.title: On anger
msItem.incipit:
185r Ira furor breuis est. animum rege. qui nisi paret⹎
Imperat. hunc frenis⹎ hunc tu compesce cathenis.
msItem.explicit: 185v Vt quid intumescit ranunculus⸝ bonis pede lesus? Nec si se ruperit par erit.

msItem.title: The rashness and audacity of Nabal
msItem.incipit: 185v Inconsulta temeritas qua usus est nabal conuitiis lacescens pueros dauid. causa fuisset subuersionis domus eiusdem⹎ nisi mitigata esset indignatio dauid. consilio abigail.
msItem.explicit: 186r Sic sic a uoluptatum illecbris⹎ perducitur quis in abyssum desperationis.

msItem.title: Short story on ignorant talk: The frogs who desired a king
msItem.incipit: 186r Petierunt rane⸝ ut natura regem eis perficeret. datus eis est malus⹎ cursui nauis⹎ ratione uetustatis multe˷ minus idoneus.
msItem.explicit: 186v Consumitur ipsarum mutilis labor. et licet ieme accedente propter ciconie recessum paulisper respirent⹎ estate tamen sequenti˷ augmentum miserie multiplicis cum fenore incurrunt.

msItem.title: On the slipperiness of the tongue
msItem.incipit: 186v Quanta sit lingue libricitas cum in udo sita sit⹎ nimis familiaribus edocemur experimentis. Non nunquam cum ex proposito utilibus indulgemus edisserendis⹎ aut minus seria aut minus ad rem spectantia partes suas interponunt.
msItem.explicit: 189r Gressus concitatus maturitatem incessus excedens. adeo ut in cursum se precipitare uideatur⹎ aut iudicium est indiscretionis aut assecla peruerse consuetudinis.

msItem.title: Short story on ignorant talk: A wren who insulted March and brought on the return of February weather; classical and biblical examples of violence against innocence; a she-wolf who stole a weasel’s cubs
msItem.incipit: 189r Parra ramo insidens calorem blandientis aure iam sentiens in primo die ditionis martis dediti februario conuicia inferre cepit.
msItem.explicit: 190v Paratus est tibi summus medicus opem set et salutem conferre. set prodolor uulnus letale occultas.

msItem.title: On the envy of the Jews
msItem.incipit: 190v Set iam tempus est ut inuidiam iudeorum subgillemus. quia ut dicit poeta.
msItem.explicit: 198v Mors equo pede regum turres ferit. et pauperum tuguria.

msItem.title: Conclusion on humility and the complexities of ignorance as a sin
msItem.rubric: 198v Ex sermone qui sic incipit. omnia tempus habent.
msItem.incipit: 198v Recedat igitur superbia ab aula pectoris nostri quia quodlibet die etiam sedendo magnam dictam facimus accedentes scillicet ad terminum uite. qui est meta proposita nobis.
msItem.explicit: 212v In cuiusmodi premio? Non temporali˷ non terreno˷ non transitorio˷ set re iocundo˷ eterno⹎ quod nec oculus uidit⸝ nec auris audiuit⸝ nec in cor hominis ascendit. quod nobis precare dignetur⸝ creator noster⸝ redemptor noster⸝ saluator noster⸝ refugium nostrum⸝ adiutor noster˷ spes nostra˷ cristus iesus⹎ qui cum patre et spiritu sancto uiuit et regnat deus⹎ per infinita seculorum secula. amen.

msItem.title: Verse envoi to Geoffrey of Malmesbury

lg.l: Nunc pater et domne tu uideris hic liber omne⹎
Seu punctum tulerit seu uiciosus erit.
Stare uelis⹎ stabit. si non⹎ hunc flamma cremabit.
Laus sua sermo tuus interitusue suus.
Si posui partes uelud is qui nesciit artes.
Hac miserere uice doctor apostolice.
Laude tui plena dedit hec rudimenta camena.
Ob decus ingenue laudis ubique tue.
Mutua discurrant inter nos pagina. nota⹎
Mens tua mensque mea sit mediante nota.
Gaudia presentis uite semperque manentis⹎
Et bona cuncta deus det tibi domne meus.

msItem.note: Adapted from Reginald of CanterburyReginald, of Canterbury, fl. 1100s, Domno Gilleberto abbati Westmonasteriensi 23–28, 37–38, 39–40; together with two lines from Alexander Neckam (1157–1217)Neckam, Alexander, 1157–1217’s poem Quem tibi transmitto doctor Radulfe nepotem (Accept, teacher Ralph, the nephew I send to you, ed. Hochgürtel, carmina metrica 17.17–18), on sending his nephew (presumably the manuscript’s compiler) to school at DunstableDunstable, Augustinian priory of St Peter.

monogr.title: The Anglo-Latin satirical poets and epigrammatists of the twelfth century

supportDesc.collation:
Quire 110+1 (ff. 3–13; 3rd added)
Quires 2–610 (ff. 14–63)
Quire 78+1 (ff. 64–71; 8th added, f. 70bis)
Quire 810 (ff. 72–81)
Quire 910+1 (ff. 82–92; 11th added, f. 92)
Quires 10–2110 (ff. 93–212) A catchword on f. 91v corresponds to f. 93r; f. 92 is an addition containing a story of a deacon of Chartres CathedralChartres, Cathedral of St Mary the Virgin from Corrogrationes Promethei. Contemporary catchwords throughout. 4r: ita ut hec corporibus

layoutDesc.layout:
170 100
Ruled in leadpoint. Written in long lines, typically 26 per page, beginning below the top line.

handDesc.handNote: At least two scribes working together: shifts visible, for example, at ff. 14r, 79v, 134v, 145r, 172r, 191r, 212v. Shifts in hand can also be found in the rubrics, such as at ff. 43r, 70v.

decoDesc.decoNote:
Margins decorated with hybrids (most often birds with human heads) and grotesques in blue and red ink. These are sometimes elaborate frames to notes on the text and relate to their subject:
f. 9r: standing figure with the note Ennon proprium est nomen hominis
f. 40r: peacock with a note on pauo
f. 145r: parrot with a note on psitacus Summaries of arguments arranged as distinctions with figurative borders at ff. 29v–30r, 35v–36r, 40v–41r. Other figural borders framing textual divisions, notes, or additions at ff. 3r, 4r, 21v, 72r, 183r, 190r.
Pen-flourished two-line initials alternating between red and blue open new sections of the text.

Citations of works from which the extracts are taken are specified by marginal rubrics, either simply framed with a line of blue ink or with simple flourishing (e.g. ff. 7r–9r), and correlated with each abstract with a red signe de renvoi.

Marginal notes are written in a triangular or circular pattern in black ink, usually with red or occasionally blue frames, explaining unusual or difficult words in the text: ff. 3r, 9r, 12v, 15r, 15v, 24v, 27r, 29r, 49v, 55v, 58v, 59r, 59v, 61v, 62r, 68v, 69v, 82r, 85r, 85v, 87r, 96r, 117v, 127r, 128v, 139r, 140r, 145r, 151r, 159v, 168r, 168v, 185r, 211r.

Some of the latter marginal notes are introduced with a paraph mark touched in red, in a format used later in the verse anthology: ff. 166v, 179v, 180r, 186v, 189r. Most of the notes are copied from the source manuscripts.
Capital letters, including versals, touched in red. The opening section has coloured versals in red and blue (f. 3r).
Rubricated headings and nota bene marks.

origin.p: Written at Cirencester Abbey, completed 1246 × 1260. The manuscript used Oxford, Jesus College, MS. 94 as one of its sources, which was at Cirencester. Passages to be quoted were marked up in the manuscript and copied directly. For example, a passage from Alexander NeckamNeckam, Alexander, 1157–1217, Tractatus super mulierem fortem on f. 169r can be found in MS. 94, fol. 120v, with both a marginal x and r marked in the margin at the beginning and end of the passage quoted. At f. 173v, the scribe copies more of Alexander’s Tractatus super parabolas than intended from Jesus College MS. 94, f. 57v.

The writer of the text names himself Galfridus and describes his offering as claustralis (f. 3r). This writer is presumably Geoffrey BritoBrito, Geoffrey, fl. 1210s–1240s (Galfridus Britonus), a canon at Cirencester Abbey in the middle of the thirteenth century who had both the education and motivation to produce Sol meldunensis. Geoffrey was the nephew of Alexander Neckam, and he quotes Alexander’s poem on sending his nephew to school at DunstableDunstable, Augustinian priory of St Peter in his conclusion (f. 212v). A document issued between 1215 and 1230 made Master Geoffrey BritoBrito, Geoffrey, fl. 1210s–1240s the vicar of Milborne PortMilborne Port, Church of St John the Evangelist, which he probably did not serve directly (Ross, no. 592). Between 1222 and 1230, Geoffrey was assigned a stall in Cirencester’s church of St John the BaptistCirencester, Church of St John the Baptist, in a charter memorializing Alexander Neckam, issued on the anniversary of his death on 31 March 1217 and naming Geoffrey as Alexander’s nephew (Ross, no. 332). Between 1230 and 1236, he was assigned a messuage near the abbey, in a charter similarly framed (Ross, no. 336). Both were witnessed by William de Blois, bishop of Worcester from 1218 to 1236William, de Blois, –1236 (where Alexander was buried), and John Walsh, abbot of Malmesbury from 1222Walsh, John, –1246?.

Geoffrey BritoBrito, Geoffrey, fl. 1210s–1240s could in theory have intended the book originally for John WalshWalsh, John, –1246? and begun work on it before 1246. Geoffrey of MalmesburyGeoffrey, of Malmesbury, –1260 is not named until f. 71v (as Gaufridus), and the irregular quire 7 corresponds to the end of Book 1, which unlike Book 2 is not designated as such with a rubric. This suggests that the text was planned initially to end with f. 69v, though the quire also precisely fits the proem to Book 2. The end of Book 2 was not yet fixed when it was copied, as the concluding verse envoi is a contemporary addition (f. 212v).

msIdentifier.msName: Inserted leaf with miniatures of friars

msItem.title: Miniature of St Francis with another friar
Miniature of St Dominic with another friar

support.material: Parchment, heavier than that used for the surrounding leaves and smaller.

decoNote.p:
Two full-page drawings tinted in brown, pink and yellow; framed in pink:
5r: St FrancisFrancis, of Assisi, Saint, 1182–1226, bearing stigmata, standing on a hillock with a younger friar. Both are barefoot, dressed in cowls, cord at waist, and carrying books.
5v: Two Dominicans, the bearded one presumably St DominicDominic, Saint, 1170–1221. Both wear hooded cloaks and walk with staffs, one T-shaped and the other with a curved top.

Zutshi dated the drawings stylistically to the middle of the thirteenth century, drawing attention to the lack of a nimbus as evidence of an earlier date and English influence. He argued that the insertion is a direct response to the surrounding text, against Little (p. 41), who saw no connection.

Nigel Morgan suggested that the artist was directly acquainted with the earlier work of Matthew ParisParis, Matthew, –1259 at St Albans AbbeySt Albans, Benedictine abbey and dated the page to the 1240s; Suzanne Lewis supported this view. Zutshi compared the iconography to a wider range of contemporary examples and did not argue for a connection to St Albans in particular.

msItem.title: Epistle of Master Geoffrey of Monmouth addressed to Alexander, bishop of Lincoln
msItem.rubric: 213v Epistula magistri Galfridi monumutensis directa Alexandro Lincolniensi episcopo
msItem.incipit: 214r Coegit me alexander lincolniensis presul nobilitatis tue dilectio prophecias merlini de britannico in latinum transferre. antequam historiam parassem⹎ quam degestis regum britannicorum inceperam.
msItem.explicit: 214r Et siquid inordinate siue incuriose protulerit⹎ ferula camenarum tuarum in rectum aduertas concentum.

msItem.title: Prophecy of Merlin
msItem.incipit: 214v Sedente itaque uortegirno rege britonum super ripam exhausti stagni⹎ egressi sunt duo dracones. quorum unus albus. et alius erat rubeus.
msItem.explicit: 222r Confligent uenti diro sufflamine. et sonitum inter sidera conficient.

layoutDesc.layout:
160 100
Ruled in leadpoint. Written in long lines, typically 20 per page, with wide line spacing (8.5 mm) that provides 3.5 mm space for glosses above each line of text.

handDesc.handNote: A shift in hand at f. 217v.

decoDesc.decoNote: Two fire-breathing dragons painted in blue, red, and orange above the beginning of Prophetia Merlini (f. 214v). These are fully shaded, in contrast to the line drawings found in most of the volume.
Added line drawings in red and blue by the decorator of the rest of the volume in the border of the opening epistle, showing two animals with human heads, one with a crown (f. 214r).
Blue two-line initials with red pen flourishing opening the two major divisions in the text, shaded to create depth in contrast to the flat colours used elsewhere in the volume (ff. 214v, 214r).
Opening rubric, likely added by one of the rubricators of the preceding part (f. 213v, copied from a trimmed guide, f. 214r).

additions.p: Added glosses in a Gothic semihybrida script, ff. 214r, 214v, 216r, 219r.

binding.p: Written with an integral parchment wrapper.

origin.p: Written in England, 1220s × 1240s. The quire may have originated at Malmesbury AbbeyMalmesbury, Benedictine abbey of St Peter and St Paul. Its contents appear to be a humorous response to the preceding material: Sol meldunensis is from one Geoffrey to another concerning the works of an Alexander, and Prophetia Merlini opens here with a letter from a Geoffrey to an Alexander (f. 214r). The wide spacing between its lines invites the addition of glosses. Its parchment wrapper would have allowed it to be added loose to the rest of the volume.

provenance.p: Cirencester AbbeyCirencester, Augustinian abbey of St Mary the Virgin: the decorator of the other parts of the volume adds a border matching the volume’s scheme (f. 214r), and the opening rubric appears to have been added by one of the Cirencester scribes (f. 213v).

layoutDesc.layout:
165 100
Ruled in leadpoint. Written in long lines, typically 30–32 per page, beginning below the top line.
A different layout is used for f. 237r–v, executed at a different stage. Ruled in leadpoint. Written in two columns of 23–30 lines, above the top line.

handDesc.handNote: A shift in hand at f. 235r.

decoDesc.decoNote: Pen-flourished two-line initials alternating between red and blue open new sections of the text.
On f. 237r–v, new stanzas exceptionally open with initials alternating between red and green, with red or blue pen flourishing.

Citations of works from which the extracts are taken are specified by marginal rubrics, often framed with a line of blue ink, the text beginning with a paraph mark (e.g. ff. 223r, 224v, 226v, 229r, etc.).
Marginal notes written in black ink, introduced with a paraph mark touched in red: ff. 224r, 224v, 225r, 231r.
Rubricated headings and nota bene marks.

origin.p: Written at Cirencester Abbey, 1246 × 1260. This part of the volume uses the same format as ff. 3–212, but the variation in contents and layout suggest it was produced at a different time. The section is less heavily annotated than other parts of the manuscript, but a hand annotating in plummet can be found across the volume (see Additions).
